subject: Learning
title: Retrieval-Induced Forgetting
description: A micro-lesson that makes Retrieval-Induced Forgetting usable.

hook.text: Practicing some items on a test can make you forget the ones you didn't practice.

buildup.text: Retrieval strengthens the memory you recall. But it also suppresses related, competing memories.

discovery.text: This is retrieval-induced forgetting: the act of remembering some things makes you forget others.

twist.text: It's not interference. The brain actively inhibits competitors to make the target easier to find.

climax.text: Witnesses who rehearse part of an event forget un-rehearsed detailsâ€”memory editing in real time.

punchline.text: Remembering can be an act of forgetting.

quiz.question: What is retrieval-induced forgetting?
options: Recalling some memories suppresses related, competing ones
